question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which scientific academy was Artur Zdunek a member of in 2035?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
**Breaking News: Renowned Agrophysicist Artur Zdunek Honored with Membership in Polish Academy of Sciences**

Warsaw, Poland - In a prestigious recognition of his outstanding contributions to the field of agrophysics, Dr. Artur Zdunek has been elected as a member of the Polish Academy of Sciences (PAS), the country's highest scientific authority. Dr. Zdunek, a distinguished agrophysicist, has made significant strides in advancing our understanding of the physical properties of agricultural products and their processing. His groundbreaking research has far-reaching implications for the development of sustainable agricultural practices, food security, and environmental conservation. "We are thrilled to welcome Dr. Zdunek to the Polish Academy of Sciences," said Professor Jerzy Duszy≈Ñski, President of the PAS. "His exceptional expertise and dedication to the field of agrophysics have earned him international recognition, and we are proud to have him among our ranks." According to the PAS, Dr. Zdunek's membership is a testament to his remarkable achievements, which have been published in numerous peer-reviewed journals and presented at esteemed scientific conferences worldwide. His work has been cited over 2,000 times, demonstrating the significant impact of his research on the scientific community. "Dr. Zdunek's election to the Polish Academy of Sciences is a well-deserved recognition of his tireless efforts to advance our understanding of agrophysical processes," said Dr. Janusz Haman, a colleague and fellow agrophysicist. "His contributions have opened up new avenues for research and innovation in agriculture, and we are honored to have him as a member of our scientific community." Data from the Polish Academy of Sciences reveals that Dr. Zdunek is among a select group of scientists who have been elected to the academy in recent years. With a membership of over 350 esteemed scientists, the PAS is a beacon of excellence in scientific research and innovation in Poland. In conclusion, Dr. Artur Zdunek's membership in the Polish Academy of Sciences is a testament to his outstanding contributions to the field of agrophysics. His election is a recognition of his dedication to advancing scientific knowledge and his commitment to improving the lives of people around the world.
content.source_2:
**Breaking News**

Renowned Agrophysicist Artur Zdunek Elected to Prestigious National Academy of Sciences

Washington D.C. - In a significant recognition of his groundbreaking contributions to the field of agrophysics, Dr. Artur Zdunek, a Polish scientist, has been elected as a member of the National Academy of Sciences (NAS), one of the most esteemed scientific organizations in the United States. The election, announced yesterday, marks a major milestone in Dr. Zdunek's illustrious career, which has spanned over two decades. His work has focused on developing innovative solutions to improve crop yields, enhance food security, and mitigate the impacts of climate change on agriculture. "I am deeply humbled and honored to be elected to the National Academy of Sciences," Dr. Zdunek said in an exclusive interview with our publication. "This recognition is not only a testament to my own research but also a tribute to the tireless efforts of my colleagues and collaborators who have worked alongside me to advance the field of agrophysics." Dr. Zdunek's election to the NAS is a significant achievement, considering the organization's rigorous selection process. The NAS, established in 1863, is a private, non-profit institution that provides independent, objective advice to the nation on matters related to science and technology. "Dr. Zdunek's election to the National Academy of Sciences is a well-deserved recognition of his outstanding contributions to the field of agrophysics," said Dr. Maria Zuber, President of the NAS. "His work has had a profound impact on our understanding of the complex relationships between plants, soil, and the environment, and we look forward to his continued contributions to the scientific community." Dr. Zdunek's research has been widely published in leading scientific journals, and he has received numerous awards for his work, including the prestigious Alexander von Humboldt Award in 2025. As a member of the NAS, Dr. Zdunek will join an elite group of scientists, engineers, and medical professionals who have made significant contributions to their respective fields. He will serve a 13-year term, from 2031 to 2044, during which he will participate in the NAS's advisory activities, including providing expert advice to the U.S. government on matters related to science and technology.
